Diese dreifachen Wesen [sind] durch (den Mangel) an [sittlicher] Haltung noch lebend als Tote zu erkennen; denn sieh, o Herr: Im Metrum Ṣāckācke || (Das Bewahren) der guten Dinge [ist] den Menschen (zugleich) Samen [und] Frucht gebend. Wer den Samen der Bewahrung in sich gesät hat, der [ist] von Menschenart. Wer aber seine (gute Art [und] Weise selbst) absichtlich unterbricht als Unverständiger, der [ist] auch lebend tot, von der guten Weise abgefallen [und] nicht von Menschenart.

These threefold beings, through (lack) of [moral] conduct, [are] to be recognized as dead ones even when still alive; for, see, lord: in the Ṣāckācke metre || (Maintaining) the good things [is] giving (, at the same time,) fruit and sees to the humans. Who[ever] has sown the seed of preservation in himself, he [is] of human kind. But who[ever] intentionally interrupts his (good way [and] manner himself) as an ignorant one, [he] is dead also while living, [has] fallen from the good manner [and is] not of human kind.
[moral] conduct even when alive they [are] to be identified as dead [ones]. For see, oh lord: In [the tune] ṣāckācke: (The observance) of the good precepts [is], to the humans,
giving (seed)s [and] fruit (at the same time). He who has sown the seed of morality in himself, he [is] of mankind. But the one who
(in)tentionally breaks (his own good way and manner himself), being ignorant, he is dead even when alive; [he has] fallen from the good way [and he is] not of mankind. 1. Having heard that,
(all being amazed) say: « Oh, what glowing of the Law, oh, what revelation of your path to enlightenment, oh, what
(cruelty of the goods who) restrain themselves.» In [the tune] c.: « This one [= the prince] has the thirty (two) marks of the Cakravartin king. Mixed [and] com(bined) with compassion
... everything [has] come about. Without compassion [is] this god Karman, unjust (?) [are] these gods, who do not reveal the seven jewels, the thousand sons,
Mitleidslos [ist] der Tatengott, ungerecht(?) [sind] die Götter, die dessen sieben Juwelen, tausend Söhne, (tausend Töchter) [und] tausend Minister nicht zur Erscheinung bringen.
Without compassion [is] the god of deeds, unjust(?) [are] the gods, who do not reveal his seven jewels, thousand sons, (thousand daughters) [and] thousand ministers.
(the thousand queens) [and] the thousand ministers [that ought to belong] to this one. » 1. Thereupon the king Brahmadatta, [being] pleased, says to the prince: « Oh lord,
(my son, teach me how,) through the cutting off (of life), death occurs! » The prince says: « Very briefly put, (the cutting off of the) life of the beings [is] of two kinds:
by dying (in a natural way) [and] dying by effort. Dying in a natural way, however, is of a three-fold kind. The first

dies (by the cessation of merits, the second) [dies] by the cessation of (possession), the third [dies] by the cessation of both, because: In [the tune] yarāssi: The life does not make dis(appear) even (the merit),

(kusne)...kotnaṣ: TB parallels are to be found in a2 (śaultsa wä)rpoṣ pāssi and b4 (śau)ltsa pāssi wärpoṣ (cf. 122).
This tune has 4x18 syllables, rhythm 7/7/4. The name may be based on a loan from Skt. jīvanta- 'living creature': c(i)w(a)ntenaṃ.
We cannot restore to triwont because the remnants of last akṣara of this line speak against ‹nt›.

Pace 25, one should rather restore wälts lāntsās '1000 queens', not 'daughters' because in the traditional list of Cakravartin jewels, one finds the queen as well as son and minister (and horses and chariots etc.), but no daughters.
